feed.title: Taylor Kitsch Burned His John Carter Loincloth (And 11 Other Things We Learned From His Toronto Visit)
feed.subtitle: After meeting the John Carter star in Toronto, we know these 12 fun facts to be true.

content.div:
If you've seen the movie posters, you're probably asking yourself one question: Who's John Carter?

Never mind the fact he's a superhero old enough to be Superman's grandpappy (Edgar Rice Burroughes published the first John Carter story in 1917), maybe you haven't read the 11 novels, or spied the 1970s comic book series. Maybe you never had a stoner uncle who decorated his basement and/or '70s panel-van with badass Princess of Mars Frazetta posters.

Here's the deal, then: John Carter is a Confederate soldier from Virginia -- a damned good one, consarnit. (The movie's goofy early action scenes featuring Carter dodging Bryan Cranston's ornery U.S. calvary recruiter are some of the liveliest.) But through some magical and mysterious quirk, Carter is transported from the badlands of the American old west to the plains of Mars. One fun thing about the Mars of turn-of-the-century science fiction: its atmosphere gives ordinary earthlings superpowers. John Carter can leap Martian buildings in a single bound! And that's all the better to help him win a few battles on behalf of his various new allies -- and, possibly, win over a feisty princess, as well.

Taylor Kitsch stars as Carter. And who's Taylor Kitsch, you ask? (Apparently someone never caught Kitsch's star-making turn as brooding small-town Texas football player, Tim Riggins, on the Peabody Award winning TV drama Friday Night Lights -- though John Carter's director, Andrew Stanton, certainly did. An episode of FNL reportedly convinced the Wall-E Oscar winner that Kitsch would make the ideal Carter.)

But again, since you asked, here's the deal: Kitsch, 30, was raised in Kelowna, educated in Lethbridge -- and after his pro hockey aspirations were dashed by a knee injury, he made for New York, studying acting and also modelling for clients including Abercrombie & Fitch, among others. His break-out role on FNL came in 2006, and with three star turns hitting theatres in the first half of 2012 -- John Carter, Battleship and the Oliver Stone-directed Savages -- he's enjoying, as everyone from Us Weekly to CNN to Kitsch himself put it, a "make or break year."

When he was in Toronto the week of John Carter's release, Dose.ca learned a few more fun facts about Kitsch, all gleaned as he gamely took questions from a room full of reporters.

Who is Taylor Kitsch? Well, we know these 12 things to be true:

1. If Kitsch is scared of a project, he'll take it -- and there were plenty of things that scared him about John Carter.

"Man, so many," he says -- starting with the script. "It took me three full reads and a white chalkboard to break it down," he says. "To do the script potential justice was, I think, scary to me, because there was so much there, and I felt there was so much to really dive into." Scary thing No. 2? "Breathing life into Andrew Stanton’s dream was a lot, to be the title guy. It wasn’t the variables of ‘Ohmigod, you’re playing THIS, you’re the lead or whatever,’ it was just this guy, he had wanted to see this thing on the screen since he was 11 years old, and it has shaped so much of him and he’s giving you the tap to play it."

2. Kitsch hates loincloths.

So what did he do with his costume after John Carter wrapped? "I burned the skirt. God."

3. Yes, Kitsch often looks pastier than an agoraphobic albino in John Carter. But there's a reason for that.

"I had to stay pale because [director Andrew Stanton] wanted me to be white, real pale for it, just to be that much different." (The other humanoid characters on Mars -- the Heliumites and the Zodangans -- are an exotic shade of Jersey Shore orange.) So I didn’t even know this existed, but I was putting on 115 or 125 SPF. I dunno, that’s crazy."

4. Kitsch wasn't a sci-fi fan growing up.

"Still not," says Kitsch -- but he doesn't think that affected his appreciation of John Carter, "because at the end of day it doesn’t matter if it’s a buddy comedy to a sci fi, horror -- hopefully it’s about the character first, and nobody’s going to put more pressure on it than me to do it justice."

5. That said, Westerns are more Kitsch's thing.

"I keep pitching [Stanton] to write me a Western so we can do it. We had so much fun doing that part of it," he says, recalling his time shooting on location in Utah and Arizona. "They built this incredible western town in this nook between two mountains and I just -- you’re living the boyhood dream, being on the horse and coming in to this town."

6. Kitsch will do anything for his art -- including enduring extreme weather while half-naked.

The actor sets the scene of a typical day shooting on location in Utah: "I’m obviously in this glorified skirt and boots and Willem [Dafoe, who plays Tars Tarkus] is on three foot stilts and pajamas, and Dejah, Lynn Collins, is in her armour, which is quite revealing as well, and you look around, and you see ... basically a sandstorm coming. And then you look around at the crew who are in military boots, jeans, huge coats, scarves wrapped around their face or bandana, goggles, and hats. And then there’s the actors standing there, just waiting, half-naked, waiting for this sand to hit you at 70 miles an hour."

7. Yes, ladies, Kitsch is dreamy. But he doesn't feel any pressure from Hollywood to maintain the John Carter physique.

"I think I’m who I am, and that hopefully doesn’t dictate who I am to other people, as well. Um -- I think, you know, I’ve also tried to lose all my muscle for a different role, so I think it’s just doing honour to whatever the role asks of you. I’d gain weight for a role if it was the right thing. So I don’t worry about that. It’s just a matter of doing the character right."

8. Kitsch's family wouldn't tell him what they thought of John Carter. Not right away, at least.

"Um. They were very quiet after the film. So I took that, obviously being sensitive, [as] 'Oh, you hate it. Sweet. Well, this is going to be awkward.' But they were really just in awe of it, the whole scene, just the film."

9. Kitsch's dream role is playing a musician.

"I don’t know that I have it down to one role. I’d love to play -- there’s something in me that wants to play a musician of some sort. I don’t know why, yet. Maybe because I just want to learn an instrument."

10. Kitsch, and the censors, should be thankful Martians bleed blue.

"We got away with a lot making the blood blue. I mean, if I was dipped in red blood coming out of the ape, it wouldn’t be PG, you know what I mean? And the decapitating and the stuff like that." (Yes, there's a scene where he cuts himself out of an ape-monster.)

11. Filming John Carter pushed Kitsch to the limits of physical exhaustion.

To achieve John Carter's loincloth-ready physique -- and handle the 150-foot jumping stunts -- Kitsch threw himself into a gruelling fitness and diet regime. "Picture yourself four months, you train every day, six days a week on a diet. And then you go to London, you’re working at 4:30 in the morning, then you’re working, training, still on that diet for seven more months. ... You’re working six to eight weeks for four of that seven months, on every single day. So it just chips away at you. There was a time when I was in Utah and there’s a small hundred-yard hill, and I came out of the trailer and I was kind of fading. Like, my body was getting smaller and I was really just exhausted and I couldn’t walk up that hill. Literally couldn’t. And I was 29 and in the best shape I’ve ever been in my life and I couldn’t get up that hill -- and it WASN’T a hill, it was like that," says Kitsch, making a slight, 10 degree angle with his hand. "So that is when I had to take a knee and I had to go. [Stanton] gave me the rest of the day off to go sleep."

12. Kitsch believes he's a star for one reason.

"I really think I’m here just by out-working people. Really. ... Everyone always asks and whatnot what the advice for young actors who are struggling and stuff -- just don’t be out-worked and you’ll be OK. Truly."

John Carter opens in theatres today.

leahc@dose.ca
